[Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology_company "Technology company") | | Founded | 1999; 27 years ago (1999) | | Founder | [Andrea Pignataro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrea_Pignataro "Andrea Pignataro") | | Headquarters | London, United Kingdom | | [Subsidiaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsidiary "Subsidiary") | - [Acuris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acuris "Acuris")

- [Fidessa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidessa "Fidessa") | | Website | [www.iongroup.com](https://www.iongroup.com/) | ION Group **ION Group** (also known as **Ion** and **Ion Investment Group**) is a [financial data](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_data_vendor "Financial data vendor") and software company headquartered in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London"). The company has expanded rapidly through a series of [acquisitions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions "Mergers and acquisitions"). The _[Financial Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times")_ has compared it to [Bloomberg L.P](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P. "Bloomberg L.P.") although it has a low profile.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:0-1) ## Background \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ION_Group&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Background")\] After studying at the [University of Bologna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Bologna "University of Bologna") **,** [Andrea Pignataro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrea_Pignataro "Andrea Pignataro") later received a doctorate in mathematics from [Imperial College London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_College_London "Imperial College London"). He then worked as a bond trader in London. While working at [Salomon Brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salomon_Brothers "Salomon Brothers"), Pignataro led a [joint venture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_venture "Joint venture") with [Pisa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pisa "Pisa")-based software firm List Holdings. The business would become Ion Trading UK, the start of ION.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:3-2) In 1999, Andrea Pignataro left Salomon Brothers in London to establish ION as an independent company.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:0-1)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:3-2) Pignataro also founded an investment firm with fellow traders after leaving Salomon Brothers but by the early 2000s, he was fully focused on Ion.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:3-2) In June 2004, [TA Associates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TA_Associates "TA Associates") made its initial investment in Ion for $44 million. It would make additional investments later for a cumulative sum of $200 million.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:1-3) Ion has expanded through a series of acquisitions, and between 2005 and 2019, Ion had acquired 20 companies reaching an [enterprise value](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterprise_value "Enterprise value") of £7 billion in November 2019.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:0-1) On 31 May 2016 [The Carlyle Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Carlyle_Group "The Carlyle Group") announced it would acquire a [minority interest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minority_interest "Minority interest") in Ion for $400 million. The following month, it was reported that Ion would buy out TA Associates' stake to fund its growth. TA Associates reportedly made almost four times its investment from the sale of its stake in Ion.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:1-3) In November 2017, [Euromoney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delinian "Delinian") sold its 15.5% stake in [Dealogic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dealogic "Dealogic") to Ion for $135 million which gave Ion a controlling stake.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-4) In April 2018, Ion acquired [Fidessa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidessa "Fidessa") for £1.5 billion by outbidding [Temenos AG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temenos_AG "Temenos AG"). The deal came just hours before the deadline set by [The Takeover Panel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Takeover_Panel "The Takeover Panel"). The deal was to enable Ion to enter the equities and derivatives markets. Ion stated it had been provided with only "limited due diligence access" with regards to Fidessa and would carry out a deeper review once the deal was completed.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-5) In April 2019, Ion acquired [Allegro Development Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegro_Development_Corporation "Allegro Development Corporation") from Vector Capital and Cerium Technology.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-6) In May 2019, Ion acquired [Acuris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acuris "Acuris") from [BC Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BC_Partners "BC Partners") for £1.35 billion to expand its product offerings for [capital markets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_market "Capital market").[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-7) There were talks of a plan to combine Ion with [Nasdaq, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq,_Inc. "Nasdaq, Inc.") in 2019. However they ended without an agreement because of concerns about whether the two would fit together. Following this and another failed bid for a financial services software business in Switzerland, Pignataro decided to consolidate control of Ion by taking out loans to buy out Carlyle's stake. After this Ion started investing in various Italian finance related companies such as Cedacri and Cerved.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ION_Group#cite_note-:3-2) In 2020, Ion acquired Broadway Technology but the [Competition and Markets Authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_and_Markets_Authority "Competition and Markets Authority") blocked Ion from buying the fixed income business of Broadway Technology due to competition concerns. A central tenet of IonQ’s strategy is the consolidation of expertise through acquisitions, most notably the proposed acquisition of [Oxford Ionics](https://quantumzeitgeist.com/airbus-partners-with-oxford-ionics-to-develop-quantum-fluid-dynamics/), aimed at accelerating progress in scalable [quantum computing](https://quantumzeitgeist.com/10-coursera-online-quantum-courses-for-learning-quantum-computing-in-2025/). This follows the completed acquisitions of Lightsynq and Capella, each contributing unique capabilities to IonQ’s roadmap. Lightsynq’s photonic interconnect technologies are particularly crucial, addressing a key challenge in scaling quantum systems – the need for high-bandwidth, low-latency communication between qubits. Capella’s expertise in infrastructure development supports the creation of a space-based [quantum key distribution (QKD)](https://quantumzeitgeist.com/speqtral-and-toshiba-digital-solutions-corporation-toshiba-collaborate-to-bring-quantum-key-distribution-qkd/) network, a critical component for secure quantum communication and a potential revenue stream. These acquisitions demonstrate a deliberate effort to build a vertically integrated quantum computing ecosystem. IonQ’s ambitious technical roadmap anticipates achieving 10,000 physical qubits with 99. 99999% logical fidelity by 2027 and 2 million physical qubits by 2030. This projection relies on advancements in qubit coherence, fidelity, and connectivity, alongside the integration of technologies acquired through strategic mergers. The company’s collaborations with leading research institutions – including the University of Washington, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, KISTI (South Korea), and AIST (Japan) – are instrumental in driving these advancements. These partnerships facilitate joint research and development, access to advanced facilities, and the exchange of expertise, accelerating the pace of innovation. Furthermore, IonQ’s $22 million deal with EPB to establish America’s first commercial quantum hub signifies a commitment to translating research into practical applications and fostering a quantum-ready workforce. The appointment of Niccolo de Masi as Chairman of the Board, succeeding Peter Chapman, reflects confidence in his leadership since becoming CEO in February 2025. These individuals bring diverse expertise in areas critical to IonQ’s success, including business development, quantum hardware, legal compliance, and scientific leadership.
